Title: Prove that an involutory matrix has eigenvalues $\pm 1$
Content: I'm trying to prove that an involutory matrix (a matrix where $A=A^{-1}$ ) has only eigenvalues $\pm 1$ . I've been able to prove that $\det(A) = \pm 1$ , but that only shows that the product of the eigenvalues is equal to $\pm 1$ , not the eigenvalues themselves. Does anybody have an idea for how the proof might go?
AcceptedAnswer: Let $\lambda$ a eigenvalue of A and $x \neq 0$ respective eigenvector, then $Ax = \lambda x \Leftrightarrow A^{-1}A x= \lambda A^{-1} x \Leftrightarrow x = \lambda A x \Leftrightarrow x = \lambda^2 x \Leftrightarrow (1-\lambda^2)x = 0$ then $\lambda =\pm 1$
